content.div:
We get it. It's Valentine's Day and you're busy. Busy wondering where to find the best chocolate liquidation sales.

Please. Don't let Jack White interrupt your plans.

Unless you're a major fan, of course.

Or maybe because you realize his new music video for "Love Interruption" will only take two minutes and 30 seconds of your precious time. You can't cram your junk into novelty underpants that quickly. (Trust us. We were watching.)

White directed the video, shot against an austere blue backdrop -- a set reminiscent of numerous Third Man record sleeves (and music videos, come to think of it). And for his first "solo" effort, the White Stripes/Raconteurs/Dead Weather mastermind sure has plenty of company: Emily Bowland on bass clarinet, Brooke Waggoner on electric piano and Ruby Amanfu on back-up vocals (though considering her croaky croon is nearly uninterrupted on "Love Interruption," we're partial to calling this one a duet).

The song, White's first single off upcoming album Blunderbuss (April 24), debuted online just weeks ago, though in the Third Man style, it's available in a range of formats for record collectors, including a limited edition Tri-Color vinyl 45 on sale as of today via the label's Nashville store and select indie music shops. (And if you feel like placing a mail order through Third Man's store, you might just luck into a copy Willy Wonka-style. They're inserting 50 copies into packages at random.)

Watch "Love Interruption" below:

leahc@dose.ca

entry.title: 2012 Grammy Awards - Best and Worst Moments

link.Abstract: It's music's biggest -- and longest -- night. Adele, Foo Fighters, Whitney Houston and more made for some of the most memorable moments of the 54th Annual Grammy Awards.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
As music's biggest night, the Grammys' mantra has always been about paying tribute to music's biggest stars. Typically, though, they're in the audience -- collecting more trophies than their Versace-clad arms can carry. That was certainly true of Sunday's edition -- with the likes of Adele, Kanye West and the Foo Fighters being lauded. But there was a heavy note to this year's show, broadcast the day after Whitney Houston's passing. The six-time Grammy winner was remembered throughout the evening, but that didn't stop the 54th Annual Grammy Awards from being the marathon, three and a half hour party it always is. Check out some of the highlights.
--Leah Collins/Dose.ca

link.Abstract: Klara Soderberg of First Aid Kit knows what it's like to be starstruck in front of her idols. Luckily, she got over it by the time she was working with them.

link.Abstract: Klara Soderberg of First Aid Kit (L) knows what it's like to be starstruck in front of her idols. Luckily, she got over it by the time she was working with them. The folk duo, long-time fans of Bright Eyes, worked with the band's Mike Mogis and Conor Oberst on new album The Lion's Roar.
link.title: First Aid Kit Interview
